Meaning: The resistance to movement exhibited by the powder.

Physical Stability. 0.9<SI<1.1 means stable. Significantly greater than unity: de-aeration, segregation, agglomeration, moisture uptake. Significantly less than unity: attrition, de-agglomeration or presence of a flow additive.
A more cohesive powder will generate higher FRI values, while free-flowing materials will exhibit a value close to unity. The presence of flow additives may generate value lower than unity.
A higher value is associated with greater friction and interlocking which may prevent the powder from flowing under certain conditions.
Efficiently packed particles with few void spaces are therefore less compressible and will typically exhibit less cohesive behavior.
A high AE measurement suggests that the sample does not effectively aerate at this air velocity. Typically, lower AE is associated with a low degree of interparticular cohesion.
A higher sensitivity to aeration, and is associated with a low degree of interparticular cohesion.

NAS represents a powder's sensitivity to a change in air velocity. The change in Flow Energy is normalised against the magnitude of the change in air velocity allowing the aeration behavior of samples requiring different air velocities to effectively aerate to be more easily compared with each other.
A high CPS indicates that the material is highly compressible

Full Name: Pressure Drop across the Powder Bed
Meaning: A high Pressure Drop across the bed indicates that it is more difficult to transmit air through the sample, and that the powder has low permeability
A high Cohesion value indicates that the powder would be more difficult to move with purely shearing force.

Full Name: Unconfined Yield Strength under 6 or 9 kPa
Meaning: A high UYS indicates that the powder bulk would be able to maintain its structure more effectively after a consolidating stress was applied and then all stresses removed, whereas a low UYS would indicate that the sample was more likely to fall apart once previously applied stress was removed.

Full Name: Major Principle Stress under 6 or 9 kPa
Meaning: A high MPS indicates that the powder behaves more like a solid than a liquid, whereas a low MPS suggests that the powder behaves more hydrostatically.

The ratio of MPS to UYS is referred to as the Flow Function. Typically, a high FF indicates a more free-flowing powder, whereas a low FF suggests that powder is highly resistant to flow under this regime.

Full Name: Angle of Internal Friction under 6 or 9 kPa
Meaning: The AIF is the angle between the x-axis and the Best Fit Line. A high AIF indicates higher friction between the powder planes, and thus a less free-flowing powder in this mode of flow.

The WFA is the angle between the x-axis and the linear Best-Fit Line to the five measured data points. A high WFA indicates that the powder would be less free-flowing against the wall surface at high stresses, whereas a low WFA suggests the powder would flow freely against the surface and not be impeded by it.
